This article offers observations on some of the challenges encountered and lessons learned while setting up and recruiting participants into a clinical trial during and after an epidemic, and makes recommendations on how these could be addressed in the future should a similar public health emergency arise. Several research groups have published their own experiences of conducting clinical trials during the Ebola outbreak, and the literature paints a picture of the context within which the EBOVAC-Salone trial was established. A number of researchers have described the difficulty of designing a robust yet ethical trial during an outbreak
5, 6 and then having to amend or abandon their original study objectives as the epidemic waned.
5, 7 Others highlighted the limitations imposed by the infrastructure of the country in which they were operating.
5 The challenges were not just for researchers: the burden on local ethics committees, dealing with huge increases in workload, was also noted.
